Here's the third column

item.title: About WP
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: Powered by WordPress, we provide an easy way for current faculty, staff and students to create a website or blog using predefined design themes and plugins. There is no charge to users.

item.title: Contact Us
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
CONTACT ASKIT

We love to listen and are eagerly waiting to talk to you regarding your project.  Get in touch with us if you have any queries and we will get back to you as soon as possible. item.content:encoded: https://www.youtube.com/embed/Zu7rRToM24k

item.title: Posts Vs. Pages
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
POSTS

TIMELY

Posts are for new and passing information. They are displayed in reverse chronological order. Think: Blog entries.

SOCIAL

Posts are ideal for sharing on social networks. They also have built-in commenting for reader discussion. For instance, you would like to comment on a post or share it on social media.

INCLUDED IN YOUR RSS FEED

Subscribers are automatically notified when new posts are published.

TOPICAL

Posts can be organized by topic using categories and tags. Posts can be found in the Archives, Categories, Recent Posts, and other widgets

PAGES

TIMELESS

Pages are for core content that won’t become outdated quickly. They are part of your website’s permanent structure. Think: About Us page.

BASIC

Pages are usually for basic content vs. sharable or discussion based content. For instance, are you going to tweet a Contact Page? Probably not.

EXCLUDED IN YOUR RSS FEED

Subscribers are not notified when new pages are created.

HIERARCHICAL

Pages can be nested by defining parent and child pages. Pages can be displayed in the sidebar using the Pages Widget, and some themes display pages in the navigation at the top of the site.

item.dc:creator: ma4474

item.title: Getting Started
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
Are you sure you have everything you need to make your site? Look at Web Publishing’s basic checklists, best practices and more to make sure that you are in the right track and to save some time.

  [iframe width="1000" height="480" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Zu7rRToM24k?autoplay=1&rel=0&controls=0&showinfo=0" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen][/iframe]    

GAME PLAN & SITE OBJECTIVES

Organizing your website content is one of the most important steps in creating a useful website, especially before selecting a theme and customizing the design. Before you start mapping out your menus and organizing your website content in neat, little packages, decide what it is you are trying to achieve. Click Here

CHECKLIST

Are you sure you have everything you need to make your site? Look at our Checklist to make sure that you have everything you need and are in the right track. It’s a great tool to save some time and get organized with content and WP tools. Click Here

BEST PRACTICES (COMING SOON!)

Following WP Best Practices will enable you to get a short cut to only those WordPress Best Practices that you need to be mindful about. Not only does this help you understand WordPress components but also be proficient at using tools or features that are specific to WP, which eventually should help you to be efficient in creating, designing and managing your WP Site. Click Here

PAGES vs. POSTS

Are you sure you have everything you need to make your site? Look at our Checklist to make sure that you have everything you need and are in the right track. It’s a great tool to save some time and get organized with content and WP tools. Click Here

item.title: WE’VE UPDATED THE SITE SETUP WIZARD!
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: Fear not, you can change your theme at any point by going to your site Dashboard > Appearance > Themes or you can try the Customizer to live preview how the theme looks once you’ve added your content.

item.title: PERFORMANCE IMPROVEMENT MAINTENANCE 10/6-10/7
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
Please be advised that the NYU Web Publishing service will undergo performance improvement maintenance from Thursday, October 6, 2016, at 6 pm until Friday, October 7 at 10 am ET. During this window, all Web Publishing sites will be visible and placed in read-only mode. If you log in, any changes you make, including the publication of pre-scheduled content, may not be saved. If you have any pre-scheduled content, please publish it before or after the maintenance window.

Any content that is added to your site by visitors during this time (via front end posting or commenting) will not be saved within the system; you may wish to add a note to your site(s) alerting visitors to this fact.

QUESTIONS?

If you have any questions regarding this information, please see the IT Service Status page for updates, or contact the NYU IT Service Desk at AskIT@nyu.edu. Thank you in advance for your patience while we make improvements to the service.

item.title: REMINDER FOR STUDENTS GRADUATING THIS FALL
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: A quick reminder for those students who are graduating in December. Users lose access to the Web Publishing service shortly after graduation (or once they’ve left the university) and their respective sites get removed from the service. If you are graduating in December 2016, please be sure to export your site at the end of the semester so that you retain all of your content. Instructions on how to export your site can be found here.

item.title: Appearance Hacks: Using Tables
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
WordPress Themes look beautiful right? When we are selecting a theme for our site, we look at its the Thumbnail Image or Screenshots in a larger screen and then decide on it. Well, once we have it installed does it really look how we expected it to look like? I am sure it does not look like those Screenshots, at least a theme that showed those beautiful grids. Well, there is a limit to which themes can help you beautify for your site. After all, not all theme builders know what kind of site content will be using this theme. Or the other way round, sometimes we ignore theme and site purpose relevance and just select a theme because it looks good, has the color or layout we were looking for. We can still achieve grids we want using tools like Tables in our WordPress editing tools or Custom CSS.

Tables

Simply use Tables from the WordPress Toolbar

The tables allow a lot of flexibility in customizing such as changing colors of borders or backgrounds, changing size of border width etcetera.

             

Use the Design Flexibility WordPress Tables Allow

Rather than just using texts, you can use images to create that grid you saw in the Theme Screenshot. You can link those images to the relevant pages or posts to make it an interactive table. Examples of some customized tables are as follows: The example used below is from a Theme that allows Tables to be Responsive The example above uses images of size 150px x 150px and uses background color Black.  

Tips:

If using images for styling, try to make sure that all images are of the same size. This will retain table aesthetics for a more appealing appearance. WordPress Tables usually have double borders. It is important to be mindful of the positions of those borders when changing the size or position of the table by (using cursor) stretching.

Use Custom CSS

More modifications to table can be made using Custom CSS. In order to use Custom CSS activate the plugin Jetpack and Custom CSS under its settings.  Such as, if changing border color to page/post background doesn’t work, you call always hide the borders using CSS code. To style Table CSS Code could be as follows. The examples below are for hiding borders of Table. Note: [sample code from WordPress Custom CSS using a Theme] 
.entry-content table {
margin-bottom: 15px;
border-collapse: collapse;
font-size: 1em;
border: solid 1px #ffffff; //Change color to background of Page/Post
}
.entry-content table tr th {
padding: 5px;
font-weight: bold;
text-align: center;
background-color: #f0f0f0;
border: solid 1px #ffffff; //Change color to background of Page/Post
}
.entry-content table tr td {
padding: 5px;
border: solid 1px #ffffff; //Change color to background of Page/Post
}
or Note: [sample code from general CSS of a HTML code for Tables] 
table {
    border-collapse: collapse;
}
or 
 td, th {
   border:none;
}
Codes to modify using CSS may vary based on the ids and classes of the specific table of your site and the type of styling you want. For instance, the class I used in the first example is specific to the WordPress theme I was using. You can always refer to open source sites such as W3Schools or StackOverFlow for guidelines if you do not have knowledge / experience of styling using CSS.  However, an important suggestion from WordPress experience would be to not try to change the default HTML code that WordPress makes. Try to use CSS on the HTML that your WordPress makes for you.

Main Catch with Using Tables

  1. Tables may not be responsive for all themes. It is important to check during designing process.
  2. The default double borders of Tables may make the table look unpleasant or messy, if not properly stretched.
  3. Adjusting color of table borders may/may not be tedious.

item.title: Top 5 Frustrations
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
Switching Themes 

‪Changing WordPress Themes is usually a tricky process. Often we overlook the fact that settings from previous themes are not directly carried over to the new one when switching themes. Some common issues that users generally face are:
  • Site settings don’t transfer. Different themes have different settings, especially with respect to Widgets and Plugins. It is important to make note of important settings before switching themes and then setting it up again.
  • Previously active widgets will not be activated automatically on switching themes. To access and activate previously active widgets, one should navigate to Dashboard > Appearance > Widgets > [Scroll below]. A list of old widgets can be found to be activated.
  • CSS styling is not carried over to new theme directly. Therefore, it is important to save stylesheet before switching themes and them reusing style sheet.
  • The site won’t look like the way its shown in thumbnail preview demo for the new theme. After switching themes you would have to customize it to make it appear as you need or like the example on thumbnail.

Managing SEO

Since WP does not offer any individual SEO plugins, users often feel restricted. However, it is important to understand that great Search Engine Optimization (SEO) requires strategy and patience. Although WordPress is one of the best content management platforms, it does not guarantee full-fledged SEO for sites, even with plugins. However, this does not restrict users from starting or trying to enhance their WP sites. There are many strategic steps one can take to enhance SEO for your Web Publishing site(s). Click here to learn more about WP SEO.

Hiding Content

Often users want to hide parts of the site like Comments, Author Information or Titles of certain posts or pages. Although solutions for such cases may vary from case to case based on the Theme being used, some common solution is to use Custom CSS. To use Custom CSS, one has to activate Jetpack plugin, and activate Custom CSS under Jetpack>Settings>Appearance. Once it is activated, navigate to Appearance > Edit CSS and add CSS code to the style sheet. If one does not have knowledge in HTML or CSS, one can use open source codes available online. Example of Code: Click here to learn more about Custom CSS.

iframe Embeds

Https issue : WordPress removes iframe html tags because of security reasons. Iframe shortcode is the replacement of the iframe html tag and accepts the same params as iframe html tag does. You may use iframe shortcode to embed content from any external page. ‪Square bracket:  The correct way to use iframe is to put you code within the square brakets. iframe embeds generally use <> brackets which is not usually read by the WP editor environment. It is important to switch <> brackets to [].

File Size

It is important to remember that the Maximum File size allowed by WP is 10MB.Often users face problems with uploading/importing content to WP sites due to File Size restrictions, whether its through Media or Tools.

item.title: Top 5 Plugins
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
Jetpack by WordPress.com

Bring the power of the WordPress.com cloud to your self-hosted WordPress. Jetpack enables you to connect your blog to a WordPress.com account to use the powerful features normally only available to WordPress.com users. For more information,  Click Here

Custom Sidebars (Custom Sidebars Pro)

Creates customized sidebars and widget areas. For more information, Click Here

Email Users

Let’s you email your users. For more information, Click Here

iframe

Let’s you embed iframes. For more information, Click Here

Calendar (Every Calendar +1 for WordPress)

Creates a calendar, that can be linked to Google calendars. For more information, Click Here

item.title: Locating Activated Plugins
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: After we activate a plugin, the plugin menu is likely to appear in either of two areas of the dashboard – 1) Main Dashboard Column 2) Under Settings. Therefore, it is important to be aware of these two dashboard areas to make our work flow easier. Example 1: Plugin appears in Main Dashboard Column Example 2: Plugin appears under Settings Note: Sometimes some specific plugin features may appear under Appearance or Tools. This typically depends on the property of plugin. For instance, while using Jetpack, if you activate Custom CSS, it will appear under Appearance. Similarly, if Attachment Importer is activated, it will appear under Tools > Import. Example 3: Plugin Feature appears under Appearance Example 4: Plugin appearance under Tools > Import

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Using Dashboard Efficiently: Locating Plugins: After we activate a plugin, the plugin menu is likely to appear in either of two areas of the dashboard – 1) Main Dashboard Column 2) Under Settings. Therefore, it is important to be aware of these two dashboard areas to make our work flow easier. Note: Sometimes some specific plugin features may appear under Appearance or Tools. This typically depends on the property of plugin. For instance, while using Jetpack, if you activate Custom CSS, it will appear under Appearance. Similarly, if Attachment Importer is activated, it will appear under Tools > Import.

item.title: Accessing Customize
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: The Customize feature of WordPress acts as a shortcut to allow users to make a lot of appearance based modifications. Customize can be accessed either from the backend (Admin Panel Dashboard) or from the frontend. The options that appear on the Customize section of Dashboard vary based on the Theme being used. Example 1: Accessing Customize from backend Example 2: Accessing Customize from frontend Example 3: Customize Section

Using Customize
The Customize feature of WordPress acts as a shortcut to allow users to make a lot of appearance based modifications. Customize can be accessed either from the backend (Admin Panel Dashboard) or from the frontend. The options that appear on the Customize section of Dashboard vary based on the Theme being used.

item.title: Accessing Comment Settings
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: Comments settings are located under Settings in Dashboard as Discussions. The Discussions part of the Dashboard allows you to make various modifications to the appearance and management of comments. To access it, navigate to: Dashboard > Settings > Discussion Discussions section of the Dashboard containing all comment management tools

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Comments settings are located under Settings in Dashboard as Discussions. The Discussions part of the Dashboard allows you to make various modifications to the appearance and management of comments. To access it, navigate to: Dashboard > Settings > Discussion

item.title: Accessing Menu Settings
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: Navigate to Dashboard > Appearance> Menu Choosing Menu Locations

item.title: SEO for WP Sites
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
Great Search Engine Optimization (SEO) requires strategy and patience. Although WordPress is one of the best content management platforms, it does not guarantee full-fledged SEO for sites. However, this does not restrict users from starting or trying to enhance their WP sites. There are many strategic steps you can take to enhance SEO for your Web Publishing site(s).

Refine your Web Publishing/WordPress settings

  • Allow your site to be indexed by search engines.
  • Remove some WordPress default content such as “Hello World” and “Sample Page”.
  • Create relevant categories for all your posts.
  • Modify your permanent link. Using the post name in the link itself is usually a good practice.
  • Avoid overuse of tags. Use limited and relevant tags,
  • Use breadcrumbs that link back to your site's homepage.

Work on your text content

  • Content must be targeted towards audience and not search engines. It is very important for content to be meaningful and authentic. Gibberish content, violates Google’s principles for good user experience, therefore such content may hamper your sites ranking on search engine. 
  • Content needs to be meaningfully unique and should be better than other competing sites that are already ranking for your chosen key words. Try to create the best content, that would enlighten users by helping them learn something new with great user experience.
  • Write long-form, in-depth content. Content should cover the main topic from as many angles as possible.
  • Write engaging headlines and introductions that drive users’ curiosity to click or read more.
  • Write content that will keep users engaged with your site.  

Image and video content 

  • Name the images on your site properly. Make sure the name is relevant to the purpose/theme of the content.
  • Similarly, add relevant content in the caption and title fields, when using the images individually or via a gallery.
  • Set the size of image files to a size that fits most screens. Typically, 940px works well for large images.
  • Similar naming conventions can be used for videos too.

Use Google

  • Use Google Analytics for tracking website traffic. Web Publishing offers a Google Analytics plugin that can be used to integrate SEO strategies with Google Analytics.
  • Submit your sitemap to Google. This helps search engines understand the organization of your web pages.

Enhance interaction

  • Allow users to comment in pages or posts where relevant.
  • Add social media sharing options, such as announcing your page or posts by using WordTwit or Twitter Tools.

Avoid outdated keyword or key phrase usage strategies

  • Try to keep yourself updated with the most up-to-date strategies and changes related to usage of keywords or key phrases for SEO purposes. 

Keep in mind

  • Writing long-form content isn’t enough if Google can’t “understand” what your content is about, so make sure long content has relevant keywords and phrases. 
  • Be careful of writing a deceptive headline that only serves as clickbait. Click-through rate as a search ranking signal may be in dispute. 
  • When new pages and posts are created it may take some time for that new URL to be indexed by search engines.

Recommendations

  • SerpIQ did a study that shows top-ranked content typically contained more than 2,000 words.
  • To speed this up, WordPress offer the chance for you to add update services within the General Settings page of your site. Ensure these four are in the list:
    • http://blogsearch.google.com/ping/RPC2 
    • http://rpc.pingomatic.com/
    • http://rpc.technorati.com/rpc/ping 
    • http://www.feedburner.com/fb/a/pingSubmit?bloglink=http:/%2www.domain.com/
  • For more information, see:
    • Wpmudev
    • Search Engine Watch
    • Yoast

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Great Search Engine Optimization (SEO) requires strategy and patience. Although WordPress is one of the best content management platforms, it does not guarantee full-fledged SEO for sites. However, this does not restrict users from starting or trying to enhance their WP sites. There are many strategic steps you can take to enhance SEO for your Web Publishing site(s).

Features vs. Plugins

Featured Images vs. Inserted Images

item.title: CHECKLIST FORM
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: [gview file="https://wp.nyu.edu/wpss4/wp-content/uploads/sites/4557/2016/12/WP-checklist-form.pdf"]

item.title: Featured Image Vs. Inserted Image
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: Featured images are usually added under a specific section of pages or posts, while inserted images are those that we insert in the visual or text area of pages or posts. Example: Adding Featured Image to a post Example: Adding Image as post content A featured image represents the contents of a post or page. Posts and pages can have a single featured image, which many themes and tools can use to enhance the presentation of your site. Featured images allow for even greater customization, by giving the option to display unique custom header images for specific posts and pages or set thumbnails for special features of your theme. An inserted image is usually a part of the content of a page or posts. Multiple images can be inserted into a page or post either directly to the visual or text area or by using special styling plugins for gallery like or slideshow appearance. Example: General locations of Featured Images and Inserted Images

item.title: Features vs. Plugins
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: Features are functions that are offered by WordPress, Themes, Widgets or certain Plugins, to enable users to add supplementary or necessary functionality to their site. Some examples of Features would be Tags, Categories, Recent Posts, Header Image or Contact Form.   Plugins on the other hand, are modules or packages of specific features, such as Custom Sidebar, Doc Embedder, Jetpack etcetera. In other words, Plugins are like specialized Widgets with multiple or specialized features. Example: Jetpack is a great example of a Plugin offering several optional features. For instance, in order to use Custom CSS or Contact Form, a user has to first activate Jetpack Plugin, then navigate to Jetpack > Settings > Appearance > Custom CSS > [activate]. Example: Most conventional WordPress features are found among the Dashboard options or under Widgets. Example: Theme based features can be found under Customize. One can access customize either from back-end by navigating to Dashboard > Appearance > Customize or from front-end by visiting site and clicking Customize.

item.title: Game plan / Site objectives
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
Organizing your website content is one of the most important steps in creating a useful website, especially before selecting a theme and customizing the design. Key Questions prior to Designing your Site Before you start mapping out your menus and organizing your website content in neat, little packages, decide what it is you are trying to achieve. Some useful questions to consider include:
  • What type of website is it? i.e. is it for a course, research project, portfolio, etc.?
  • Who is the audience of the site? i.e. students, faculty, the NYU community, the world.
  • What is the goal of the site? I.e. A resources for students, a place for students to submit their work, to showcase a body of work, to disseminate a research project to the larger community, etc.
  • What types of content to you have? Images, video, pdfs, etc?
  • How often will content be updated or added to the site? i.e. for a course site, both faculty and students may be posting regularly whereas on a resource site, content may be added and updated on a semesterly basis.
Gathering and Organizing your Content Now that you’ve defined the goal and user base of the site, it’s time to start gathering and organizing your content. Some useful steps in doing so include:
  • Gather your content: Assemble all your content and ensure it is current, accurate, and consistent prior to designing your site. You can only decide upon a website structure if you know what it is you’re structuring in the first place. If you attempt to do this before you have your content, you will most likely spend a lot of time updating and reworking it over the course of your project.
  • Conduct a Card sort. Once you have collated the content for your website, it’s a good idea to run a card sort - Card sorting is a method used to help design or evaluate the structure of a site. In a card sorting session, participants create topic cards, organize those topics into categories, which create the underlying structure of the site. This is a great way to organize content on your website and will help you understand your users' expectations and understanding of your topics. It is often most useful once you have done some homework to find out about your users and understand your content. Knowing how your users group information can help you:
  • Build the structure for your website.
  • Decide what to put on the homepage and sidebar
  • Label categories and navigation
  • Create a visual sitemap. Now that you have your main groupings, you can begin to categorize the other content under each grouping title. Go through your brainstorming session and begin to move the content under your main grouping headings. Visualising this structure will clearly shows the relationships between pages and posts, and tell you where your website is too shallow or deep. More importantly, it will help you prioritize the level at which content is displayed.
These steps provide the game plan for better understanding your users' expectations as well as your content topics and sets you up for designing a site that best represents your content and goals.

item.title: Checklist
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
Are you sure you have everything you need to make your site? Our Checklist will help you make sure that you have everything you need. It’s a great tool to save some time and get organized with content and WP tools.

  • Outline

  • Content

  • Design

  • Themes

  • Plugins

  • Settings

Use our list below to check off everything you have.  Email the list to yourself, to have it handy and print ready!

item.title: Reminder for Students Graduating this Fall
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: A quick reminder for those students who are graduating in December. Users lose access to the Web Publishing service shortly after graduation (or once they’ve left the university) and their respective sites get removed from the service. If you are graduating in December 2016, please be sure to export your site at the end of the semester so that you retain all of your content. Instructions on how to export your site can be found here.

item.title: Performance Improvement Maintenance 10/6-10/7
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
Please be advised that the NYU Web Publishing service will undergo performance improvement maintenance from Thursday, October 6, 2016, at 6 pm until Friday, October 7 at 10 am ET. During this window, all Web Publishing sites will be visible and placed in read-only mode. If you log in, any changes you make, including the publication of pre-scheduled content, may not be saved. If you have any pre-scheduled content, please publish it before or after the maintenance window.

Any content that is added to your site by visitors during this time (via front end posting or commenting) will not be saved within the system; you may wish to add a note to your site(s) alerting visitors to this fact.

Questions?

If you have any questions regarding this information, please see the IT Service Status page for updates, or contact the NYU IT Service Desk at AskIT@nyu.edu. Thank you in advance for your patience while we make improvements to the service.

item.title: We’ve updated the Site Setup Wizard!
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
Now you can select a theme while creating your site!

Fear not, you can change your theme at any point by going to your site Dashboard > Appearance > Themes or you can try the Customizer to live preview how the theme looks once you’ve added your content.

item.title: CSS AND JAVASCRIPT ISSUE RESOLVED
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: The issue regarding sites not loading correctly has been resolved and all sites should now be loading properly. Again, thank you for your patience and understanding.

item.title: CSS and Javascript not loading
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: We’re aware of the issue and are working to resolve it asap. Your content remains unaffected and the appearance will be restored. We’ll post an update once we have new information. Thanks for your patience.

item.title: Reminder: Outdated themes will be removed July 1
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: Reminder to all Web Publishing users: The Web Publishing service will remove out-of-date themes on July 1, 2016. Because certain old themes are no longer supported by the WordPress community, we must remove them, plus several plugins, to keep this environment secure. See the full list We have added many new WordPress themes for you to choose from. Also, your posts, pages and media will remain unchanged, however, you’ll need to switch to a new theme if one from the list is currently active on one or more of your sites. Otherwise, the system-wide default theme will be applied to your site. We apologize for this inconvenience. Please direct any questions to the NYU IT Service Desk. We appreciate your patience while we improve the Web Publishing environment. Thank you, The Web Publishing Team

item.title: Spring Cleaning Timeline and Update
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
NYU Information Technology and the NYU Web Publishing Team have completed a Spring Cleaning timeline, plus a plugin and theme audit, and we’ve identified new features that we will implement according to the following schedule: On May 20th, 2016, we will update the Web Publishing service to the latest version of WordPress and we will integrate Jetpack, a plugin that offers lots of exciting new features. On May 27th, we will add approximately 20 new themes to the service and remove a number of outdated themes and plugins. On June 6th, all sites that have not been updated in more than a year (since May 19th, 2015), as well as sites that are still owned by alumni, will be permanently deleted from the service. No backup will be available. Be sure to transfer your site’s ownership to a current user or export your site. On July 1st, the remainder of outdated plugins and themes will be removed from the service.

What you have to do?

    1. If you have a Web Publishing site that has not been updated since May 19th, 2015 and –
      1. would like to keep that site, please log in to that WP site and make a small change or edit. Any sites that have not been updated in more than a year from 5/19/16 will be permanently deleted from the service. No backup will be available.
      2. would like to export your site, please follow these instructions on how to export your site.
    2. If you are using the Social Media plugin, the Contact Form plugin, or one of the themes that are being removed, please follow the linked instructions to make sure you don’t lose any content or customizations.
    3. If you are an alumni or if you use a site owned by an alumni and require that your site remains live, please update the site owner to a current faculty, staff or student netID before May 27th or the site will be deleted and no backup will be available.

Questions?

If you have any questions regarding this information, please contact the NYU IT Service Desk at AskIT@nyu.edu. We appreciate your support while we make improvements to the service.

item.title: NYU Web Publishing Spring Cleaning
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded:
NYU Information Technology and the NYU Web Publishing Team are conducting a review of all plugins, themes, and sites in preparation for its first annual Spring Cleaning. This means that new features are coming to the service to better support the growing needs of the NYU community. This also means two important things for you:
  1. Any plugins and themes that are no longer supported by the WordPress community (i.e. out of date or not compatible with the latest version of WordPress) will be removed from the service.
  2. Any websites that have not been updated in more than a year will be removed from the service.
The Web Publishing team is working hard to find replacements for any functionality that will be removed and will try to make this a smooth transition. This Spring Cleaning will begin on May 26th, after the Spring semester ends so as not to impact any courses or sites during the term.
What you have to do?
If you have a WP site that has not been updated in over a year and would like to keep that site, please login to that WP site and make a small change or edit. Any sites that have not been updated in over a year from May 19, 2016 will be permanently deleted from the service.
Questions?
If you have any questions regarding this information, please contact the NYU IT Service Desk at AskIT@nyu.edu. Stay tuned for more information regarding which themes and plugins will be removed and which new features are coming to the service. Thank you in advance for your support while we make improvements to the service.

item.title: Reminder about WP Eligibility
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: A quick reminder for those students who are graduating in May. Users lose access to the Web Publishing service shortly after graduation (or once they’ve left the university) and their respective sites get deleted. If you are graduating in May 2016, please be sure to export your site at the end of the semester so that you retain all of your content. Instructions on how to export your site can be found here.

item.title: NYU Web Publishing sites will be uneditable 3/18-3/19
item.dc:creator: ma4474
item.content:encoded: Please be advised the NYU Web Publishing service will be undergoing a performance improvement maintenance from Friday, March 18, 2016, at 4:00 pm until Saturday, March 19 at 4:00 pm ET. During this time, all Web Publishing sites will be placed in read-only mode, and users will not be able to login to add, edit, or change any content on their site(s). Any content that is added to your site by visitors during this time (via front end posting or commenting) will not be saved within the system; you may wish to add a note to your site(s) alerting visitors to this fact.
